James Boyd was shot to death by Albuquerque, N.M., police when he was found 
camping in an unauthorized area of the Sandia foothills. Police accused him 
of antagonizing them with a knife.
A mentally ill homeless man who was shot to death by Albuquerque, N.M., 
police while armed with a knife suffered three gunshot wounds, including 
one to his back, a shocking autopsy report has revealed.
James Boyd's battered body underwent an arm amputation and the removal of 
his spleen, part of his large intestine, and left lower lung lobe in a 
desperate effort by doctors to save him after the March 16 shooting, the 
report obtained by KOB shows.
One bullet was described as having entered his lower back before passing 
through his lower abdomen, exiting his left armpit and entering his upper 
left arm.

The Cops have to stand trial for murder. Looking at the tape several times, 
the man had two knifes in his hands, and turned away still holding the 
knives, which prompted the first Cop with the M-4 rifle to shoot, and the 
second Cop (with the helmet cam) also with an M-4 to shoot apparently in 
response to the first shots being fired.

The whole case will hinge on what actual or perceived threat the man posed 
in the split second between him turning away and the two Cops firing the 
lethal rounds. No doubt the Cops attorneys will argue that the man could 
have been turning away in an attempt to grab a gun from his bag, thus 
justifying lethal force.

Where the wheels went off the bus was when the flash bang had little to no 
effect on the man's ability to hold the knives or stand his ground. Their 
assault and take down was aborted, but not before they closed to the point 
their options were limited. His turning was the final factor.

I think they will be acquitted, but the Cops are still guilty of extremely 
poor judgment and piss poor tactics. Beyond the shooting itself, note how 
the Canine Officer is being flagged (having a gun pointed near his head) by 
the first Cop with the M-4, and how the helmet cam Cop didn't have to 
shoot, but did so anyway, even when his rounds were going dangerous close 
to the two Cops to his right. A single stumble on the rocks and he not the 
suspect could have killed two Cops. ﻿

July 1st 2014, 

Today on my blog, I wanted to share a video about a more recent case of 
police brutality in New Mexico. Where a man by the name of James Boyd, a 
homeless man is found when police officers were doing an illegal camping 
arrest in the area. What lead to this police brutality was a three-hour 
argument with the three police officers ending in the officer’s flash 
banging, shooting him with multiple rounds from their rifles, shooting him 
with beanbag rounds out of a shotgun, and letting the k-9 attack him all as 
he was going to come down from where is was camping and had his back turn 
towards the police officers with his hands in the air. If this does not 
count as police brutality, then I really don’t know what to say. These 
police officers did not lose control over the situation and Boyd a homeless 
man with a few pocket knifes was shoot and pronounced dead at the hospital 
over an arrest for illegal camping. The idea of masculinity and control 
over a situation by using excessive force is unnecessary and wrong. Do 
these officers commit these acts of violence due to masculinity or by 
order, clearly hearing someone say “do it” in the video clip. Are these 
officers going against their own beliefs to fallow orders from someone who 
holds power and ideally someone who is more masculine? Watch this video and 
let me know how you feel about police brutality, but before watching this

+TheOpelkoenjas Thank you for bringing up the word EMPATHY. The Golden Rule 
is pointless when we subtract EMPATHY. I am working towards earning my PhD 
and the study of ETHICS is my main research focus. Empathy is part of 
ethics. Without empathy it is virtually impossible for the Golden Rule to 
have any meaning. As a former Dallas, TX cop I was incensed at the callous 
nature and reaction of these people. That was a human being that was just 
shot with a BURST of gunfire. The distance was considerable. Meaning where 
was the imminent threat to the officers? Back off and de-escalate the 
situation please. He is lying on the ground with numerous gunshot wounds 
and they handcuffed him? No sense of urgency to check for breathing. I 
really do not get the calm attitude. He was someone's son or father or 
husband. He was obviously homeless which is an immediate heads up for 
possible mental illness. I am a big cop supporter. The job is thankless and 
extremely dangerous. Cops not only have to deal with the scum of the earth, 
they also have to deal with Monday-morning quarterbackers who think they 
have the right to second-guess cops for every imagined slight real or 
otherwise. I just think in this case the calloused attitude was disturbing. 
I believe this is indicative of how we as a people are becoming very 
desensitized to other people; a loss or inability to have true empathy. 
Without empathy how can we ever progress in the area of social justice? We 
can not and we are not progressing. I am indicting all of us. It is the 
biggest problem with humanity in general. We care about ourselves and 
expect everyone else to care about us but let the other poor schmuck fend 
for himself or herself right? It's not our problem right? We don't want to 
get involved right? We might be late for work or picking up the kids if we 
help or speak up or defend someone weaker and defenseless right? There is a 
bigger issue here than just cops being insensitive. It is a cultural, 
global issue.

In reality, thrown knives have negligible stopping power because they lack 
three crucial elements: Mass, velocity, and accuracy. -It takes quite a lot 
of force to push a knife through skin and muscle and bone. The force with 
which a weapon hits its target is determined by its mass and its velocity. 
Knives are relatively light — an alleged throwing knife weighs only 50 
grams (~1.8 oz). The heaviest knife still only weighs 310 grams (~11 oz) -a 
thrown knife will lose what little velocity it has very quickly, making it 
next to useless at long range. The end-over-end spin also means that a 
knife spends very little time with its pointy end towards its target. Even 
a talented knife thrower is more likely to hit the target with the side or 
the butt of the knife rather than its point when the target is moving, as 
in a melee. Combine that with the knife’s limited range, and your rabid dog 
would probably be better off walking up to the good guy and stabbing him in 
the face. -
